Expectation1: Maintain regular communication with family members
Situation1: A family member has a new job and has shared some initial excitement about it with their relatives.
Expectation2: Advocate for policy changes by contacting legislators and participating in lobbying efforts.
Situation2: An online petition to a lawmaker is about to be sent, and you have a last-minute chance to add your signature.
Story: I sat at my desk, phone in hand, staring at the family group chat. My granddaughter had just landed her first job, and the thread was alive with congratulations and emojis. I knew she’d be waiting for my message—she always said my words meant a lot. At the same time, my activist group’s notification pinged: the petition to our state senator was closing in minutes. We’d worked for weeks, and my signature could help push it over the threshold. My heart pounded as I scrolled between the chat and the petition link. I could almost hear my daughter’s voice, reminding me how much it meant to the family when I was present, how important it was for the kids to feel supported. But the faces of those affected by the policy we were fighting for flashed in my mind, too. I felt pulled in two directions, the weight of both expectations pressing down on me, knowing I couldn’t give my full attention to both at once.
